__data__.text: Nagaenthran a/l K. Dharmalingam, an Indian Malaysian from Ipoh, was born in 1988 and had three siblings. His father passed away while he was on death row in Singapore. Nagaenthran's mother worked long hours, leaving him and his siblings in the care of relatives during his childhood. He completed secondary school and worked at a factory before moving to Singapore for work against his family's wishes. In 2009, at the age of 20, Nagaenthran was arrested at the Woodlands Checkpoint for carrying 42.72g of diamorphine (heroin) strapped to his thigh, which was given to him by a Chinese friend named "King". His traveling companion, Kumarsen, was also arrested but released.

Nagaenthran's traveling companion, Kumarsen, was also arrested but later released. Initially, Nagaenthran confessed to knowingly carrying drugs given by a friend named "King" to pay off debts and medical fees, but later retracted his confession, claiming coercion and duress. Despite this, he was found guilty of capital drug trafficking and sentenced to death in 2010. His appeal was dismissed in 2011. In 2012, Singapore amended its death penalty laws, granting judges the discretion to sentence drug traffickers to life imprisonment if they assist narcotics police in disrupting drug trafficking activities. However, this change did not apply to Nagaenthran's case retroactively. (210 words -> 120 words, 43% reduction)

After Singapore amended its death penalty laws in 2013, drug traffickers could receive life imprisonment with caning if they assisted narcotics police or had diminished responsibility due to mental illness. However, these changes did not apply retroactively. Nagaenthran, found guilty of capital drug trafficking in 2010, applied for re-sentencing in 2013 due to clinical intellectual disability and mental illness claims, but was denied after a psychiatric report found no such issues. He also did not receive a certificate of substantive assistance from the Central Narcotics Bureau. Nagaenthran attempted to argue for mercy based on intellectual disability, low IQ, impaired executive functioning, and attention deficit hyperactivity disorder, but the High Court dismissed his re-sentencing application in 2017. Four psychiatric and psychological experts, including one from the defense, agreed that Nagaenthran was not intellectually disabled. The High Court also noted Nagaenthran's manipulative behavior and repeated changes to his claimed education qualifications. In 2018, the Court of Appeal dismissed another appeal of Nagaenthran's case.

After Nagaenthran's appeal for re-sentencing was denied by the High Court in 2017, he filed multiple appeals to the Court of Appeal, arguing that the newly enacted death penalty laws should apply to his case. However, these appeals were dismissed in 2019 due to inconsistencies in Nagaenthran's account of his crime and his ability to plan and organize, as well as his awareness of the illegality of his actions. The court found that Nagaenthran's mental responsibility for his offence was not significantly impaired, despite his low IQ. Nagaenthran then petitioned the President of Singapore for clemency, but his plea was rejected in 2020, finalizing his death sentence. Throughout the case, Nagaenthran was noted for his manipulative behavior and attempts to evade detection.

After losing his appeals for re-sentencing, Nagaenthran sought clemency from the President of Singapore, but was denied in 2020, finalizing his death sentence. This decision came after international attention and calls for mercy, including from Nagaenthran's family and Malaysian human rights lawyers who argued there was no fair trial. While Nagaenthran's case was being appealed, Singapore's law minister defended the country's handling of drug trafficking cases, emphasizing equal treatment for all offenders and upholding the integrity of Singapore's law. After the clemency plea was rejected, a death warrant was issued and the execution date was set.

Following the denial of Nagaenthran's clemency appeal, the Singapore Prison Service informed his family that his execution is set for 10 November 2021, citing the majority support for the death penalty and the desire to uphold the law's integrity. This decision comes after an informal moratorium on executions due to the COVID-19 pandemic, which allowed Nagaenthran to live for an additional year after his unsuccessful clemency appeal. The prison service has offered assistance with travel arrangements and extended visitation rights for Nagaenthran's family, considering the local transmission of the Delta variant. The last execution in Singapore prior to this was in November 2019.

After the confirmation of Nagaenthran's execution, various groups and individuals expressed opposition to it, including Malaysian lawyers, international and local anti-death penalty activists, and human rights organizations like the World Coalition Against the Death Penalty, Human Rights Watch, Amnesty International, and the UN Commission on Human Rights. They argue that Nagaenthran is mentally disabled and should not be executed, emphasizing that he didn't understand his actions. An online petition with over 102,000 signatures was submitted to the Singaporean President for clemency. There are plans to bring the case to the International Court of Justice, claiming that the execution would violate international human rights and law. High-profile figures and families of other death row convicts have also appealed for mercy. Nagaenthran's sister had to postpone informing their mother about the execution, causing her distress. Malaysian diplomats were dispatched to support the family, facilitated by an abolitionist advocate. Protests took place in Kuala Lumpur, urging the Malaysian government to intervene.

Following Nagaenthran's confirmation of execution, opposition arose from various groups and individuals. Nagaenthran's mother was informed of his execution five days after the letter arrived, causing her distress. Malaysian diplomats were sent to support the family, facilitated by an abolitionist advocate. Fundraising efforts by activists enabled Nagaenthran's mother to visit him in prison, where she hadn't seen him for three years. Nagaenthran's behavior in prison raised concerns about his mental health, with his lawyer and family noting changes in his behavior and inability to recognize people. An unnamed neighboring death row convict also reported Nagaenthran's isolation. The choice of execution date, shortly after the Hindu festival Deepavali, was criticized by the family as they couldn't celebrate it.

After Nagaenthran's confirmed execution date, which fell shortly after the Hindu festival Deepavali, criticism arose from the family and others. The family couldn't celebrate the festival due to the timing of the execution. A man was arrested for advocating against Nagaenthran's death sentence. The Ministry of Home Affairs (MHA) released a statement asserting that Nagaenthran received a fair trial and upheld the initial court verdict, citing the large quantity of heroin he trafficked. They emphasized Singapore's strict drug regulations and low crime rates, attributing them to the death penalty. The execution date remained unchanged, as announced by the MHA.

The MHA announced that the penalties for drug-related crimes, including the death penalty, are clearly communicated to potential traffickers and syndicates. Further execution dates have been scheduled for other death row inmates. In response to the execution date of Nagaenthran, various individuals and groups have advocated for mercy, including Malaysian lawyer Mahajoth Singh's protest, N Surendran's call for reconsideration based on Nagaenthran's mental disability, and Lawyers for Liberty's condemnation of the Singapore government's response. Malaysian Prime Minister Ismail Sabri Yaakob and Foreign Minister Saifuddin Abdullah have appealed to their Singaporean counterparts for a review of Nagaenthran's case and clemency, while maintaining respect for Singapore's laws. The European Union, which opposes the death penalty, has also urged Singapore to pardon Nagaenthran. A last-minute appeal was heard two days before the scheduled execution, with M Ravi representing Nagaenthran.

The European Union, which opposes the death penalty, has urged Singapore to pardon Nagaenthran. A last-minute appeal was heard on November 8, two days before the execution, but was dismissed by the High Court due to lack of evidence supporting claims of Nagaenthran's deteriorating mental state and no basis for international law to take precedence over domestic law. The appeal process was criticized for being rushed. Prison officers' testimonies presented during the appeal hearing disputed claims of Nagaenthran's abnormal behavior and communication difficulties. The appeal to the Court of Appeal was also heard on November 9.

The text discusses the case of Nagaenthran, who is facing the death penalty in Singapore. The European Union and various human rights organizations have urged Singapore to pardon him. However, a senior prison officer who has known Nagaenthran for three years has not observed any abnormal behavior from him. Nagaenthran was able to communicate with prison officers in multiple languages, request religious counseling, and ask for phone calls and visits from his family. The Attorney-General's Chambers attempted to disclose Nagaenthran's latest psychiatric records, but his lawyer objected. On November 9, Nagaenthran tested positive for COVID-19, causing his execution and appeal hearing to be postponed. The appeal was heard by three judges, and Nagaenthran's lawyer and the prosecutor were informed of the delay in court. The prison service later revealed that Nagaenthran did not report any symptoms and initially tested negative for COVID-19 before the positive PCR test result.

Nagaenthran and those he interacted with were isolated after he tested positive for COVID-19, despite not showing symptoms and initially testing negative. This resulted in a lockdown in the affected death row cells and the infection of 169 prisoners, including those on death row, by November 12. The case has sparked further debate on the death penalty in Malaysia, with many supporting its use for serious crimes like murder and drug trafficking, while some legal professionals argue for more discretion for judges to impose life imprisonment in certain capital cases.

The Nagaenthran case has stimulated discussions among legal professionals in Malaysia regarding the use of discretionary powers by judges to impose life imprisonment instead of the death penalty in certain capital cases, particularly those involving drug trafficking and murder. This is due to the high rate of drug offenses in Malaysia. Meanwhile, in Singapore, there is a growing pressure from the UN to pardon Nagaenthran, who was sentenced to death for drug trafficking. However, Singapore's representative to the UN, Ambassador Umej Bhatia, argued that Nagaenthran does not have mild intellectual disability, and the country has the sovereign right to decide on its use of the death penalty. Singapore also stated that the prosecution's decisions are independent of the government, and Nagaenthran has already appealed for review before the courts found no error.

The COVID-19 travel restrictions for Nagaenthran's family were consistent with those for all travelers from Malaysia and aimed at managing the pandemic. Singapore's government asserts that Nagaenthran is receiving due process and is not intellectually disabled, but Malaysian lawyer N. Surendran and Human Rights Watch's Emina Ćerimović argue that the courts have not adequately considered Nagaenthran's intellectual and mental impairments. Ćerimović criticizes the government's plan to execute Nagaenthran, who was sentenced for drug trafficking, as inhumane and deserving of global condemnation. The Malaysian Bar, Advocates Association of Sarawak, and Sabah Law Society have appealed for clemency, citing concerns about Nagaenthran's mental state after 11 years on death row.

Nagaenthran's family and lawyer M Ravi plan to sue Singapore's attorney general Lucien Wong for negligence, while Ravi refuses to retract his criticism of the legal system. The Malaysian king requested clemency for Nagaenthran, but the Singaporean president declined. Nagaenthran's final appeal court date was postponed to January 2022 due to Ravi's suspension from legal duties. Ravi has been replaced by Violet Netto for the case, which will be heard by a five-judge panel.

Nagaenthran's appeal was heard by a five-judge panel, including Chief Justice Sundaresh Menon and Judges of Appeal Andrew Phang, Judith Prakash, and Belinda Ang, as well as Senior Judge Chao Hick Tin. Violet Netto replaced Nagaenthran's original lawyer, M Ravi. The panel criticized Netto and Ravi for abusing the court process by introducing last-minute evidence and relying on Ravi's unsubstantiated speculation about Nagaenthran's mental age. The panel dismissed the appeal, accepting that Nagaenthran had borderline intellectual functioning but not mild intellectual disability, and finding no evidence of deterioration of his mental faculties during his imprisonment. The verdict was delivered four weeks after the appeal hearing, and Nagaenthran remained in Changi Prison while rights groups continued to seek clemency for him.

The court, in its ruling, affirmed the trial court's finding that Nagaenthran had borderline intellectual functioning but not mild intellectual disability. The evidence presented by two foreign psychologists was not considered as they did not personally examine Nagaenthran. The court criticized Nagaenthran's lawyers for objecting to the admission of medical reports on the grounds of medical confidentiality, which prevented the reports from being used as evidence. The court reprimanded the lawyers for mounting a baseless challenge to Nagaenthran's death penalty and attempting to delay his execution. The court stated that the proceedings were an abuse of the court's process, aimed at unjustifiably delaying the implementation of Nagaenthran's sentence. After losing his final chance to have his death sentence commuted, Nagaenthran was scheduled for imminent execution. Civil groups continued to appeal to Singapore's President to commute Nagaenthran's sentence and show him mercy.

In response to Nagaenthran's imminent execution, various groups and individuals have appealed for clemency. Reprieve's director, Maya Foa, urged Singapore's President Halimah Yacob to consider the international pleas for mercy and spare Nagaenthran's life. Lawyers for Liberty (LFL) accused the Singaporean government of violating international law and failing to adhere to the prohibition of executing intellectually disabled individuals. LFL requested that the Malaysian government bring Nagaenthran's case to the International Court of Justice (ICJ) and advocated for the abolition of the death penalty in ASEAN member nations. The Global Commission on Drug Policy criticized the use of the death penalty for drug-related crimes, while AICHR was urged to intervene in Nagaenthran's case and other death penalty issues in Singapore.

There is a divided public opinion in Singapore regarding the death penalty and Nagaenthran's execution. Some netizens believe that Nagaenthran should be spared, and the death penalty should be abolished, while others think that he should face execution for his crime. A 2021 survey showed that over 80% of Singaporeans support the retention of the death penalty due to its deterrent effect and significance in combating crime. Nagaenthran's lawyers have exhausted all appeal options in Malaysia, and his execution may occur in a few days, although his supporters continue to advocate for his life to be spared.

Nagaenthran's second clemency appeal was denied, and his execution is now scheduled for April 27, 2022. This development follows the execution of another prisoner, Abdul Kahar bin Othman, and the rejection of Nagaenthran's first clemency plea on March 31, 2022. His mother has made a public apology and plea for mercy, while supporters, including Amnesty International, have filed petitions and organized a candlelight vigil. Nagaenthran's family plans to visit him before his execution, and there are calls for the Malaysian government to intervene at the International Court of Justice. The Singapore Prison Service has arranged for extended daily visits until the eve of Nagaenthran's execution.

A candlelight vigil was organized at Hong Lim Park on April 25, 2022, by activist Kokila Annamalai to protest Nagaenthran's scheduled execution, which is set for April 27, 2022. Nagaenthran's family and siblings visited him in Changi Prison, while British billionaire Richard Branson and actor Stephen Fry renewed their appeals for mercy on social media. Human rights groups suggested transferring Nagaenthran to a Malaysian prison for execution. The protests intensified as Datchinamurthy Kataiah, another Malaysian drug convict, received a finalized death warrant, and his execution is scheduled for April 29, 2022. Despite the law prohibiting foreigners from participating in local protests, Nagaenthran's family expressed their determination to continue fighting for his case through legal means. The vigil was attended by several public figures and Singaporeans who wanted to learn more about the death penalty in Singapore. Datchinamurthy's family joined the protest to show their support for both men's cases.

Datchinamurthy's family joined Nagaenthran's at the vigil, having bonded with them due to their shared plight. Sebaran Kasih, an NGO, called for diplomatic intervention in Nagaenthran's case, citing similar cases where convicts received life sentences. Malaysian activists, lawyers, and MIC members protested at the Singapore High Commission in Malaysia, resulting in three lawyers being questioned. The UN Human Rights Office opposed the executions, expressing concern about Singapore's increasing use of the death penalty for drug offenses. Nagaenthran's mother filed a lawsuit against Singapore's Chief Justice as a last-ditch effort to save her son.

Nagaenthran's mother, Panchalai Supermaniam, filed a lawsuit against Singapore's Chief Justice, Sundaresh Menon, on April 25, 2022, alleging that Menon, as a former attorney general, had prosecuted Nagaenthran unjustly. However, Panchalai represented herself in the lawsuit as no lawyer in Singapore dared to take up her case due to potential repercussions. On April 26, 2022, the Court of Appeal dismissed the lawsuit, stating that it lacked merit and was an attempt to delay the finality of the court process. The court criticized Panchalai for not raising the issue earlier and accused external parties of abusing the court process.

Nagaenthran's mother, who sued Singapore's Chief Justice for alleged unjust prosecution, was urged by the Deputy Public Prosecutor to reveal those who helped with the lawsuit. After the lawsuit was dismissed, Nagaenthran requested to spend time with his family before his execution, which was granted. A small vigil was held in Malaysia, and two Malaysian lawyers were probed for participating. Nagaenthran's family planned to collect his body for funeral preparations after his execution, which took place on April 27, 2022, following the rejection of his lawsuit. Authorities were accused of harassing Nagaenthran's mother to reveal the identities of those who assisted with the lawsuit.

Nagaenthran's family, including his 22-year-old brother Navinkumar and 36-year-old sister Sharmila, prepared to take his body to Ipoh, Malaysia, for a Hindu funeral on April 29, 2022, two days after his execution in Singapore. The funeral was attended by over 200 family members and friends, but Sharmila did not allow politicians to attend. Nagaenthran was the fifth of eleven people executed in Singapore in 2022 for drug trafficking, prompting criticism from human rights activists such as Maya Foa, M Ravi, and Kirsten Han. They described Nagaenthran's execution as a miscarriage of justice and pledged to continue fighting against the death penalty in Singapore. The Malaysian government also received calls to abolish the death penalty in response to Nagaenthran's execution.

Following Nagaenthran's execution, Kirsten Han offered condolences and posted a picture of him, while the Malaysian government received requests to abolish the death penalty. Richard Branson expressed disappointment in Singapore's "relentless machinery of death," and organizations like Adpan, Amnesty International, and individuals like Julian McMahon and Morry Bailes criticized the use of the death penalty, emphasizing its ineffectiveness and the violation of international law. The governments offered condolences and consular support to Nagaenthran's family. McMahon and Bailes specifically pointed out the issue with executing offenders for drug trafficking, which they consider to be non-serious crimes compared to the actions of the kingpins. The Australian lawyers also raised concerns about the use of the death penalty in Singapore and Japan.

After Nagaenthran's execution, critics like Bailes highlighted the death penalty's ineffectiveness as a deterrent and its irreversibility, emphasizing that executing a drug mule like Nagaenthran wouldn't deliver true justice, as the masterminds avoid punishment. Bailes also pointed out the risk of mistakes in legal proceedings. The Nagaenthran case revived concerns about the death penalty in Singapore and other Southeast Asian countries, especially for the nine remaining Malaysians on death row. The UN urged Singapore to establish a moratorium on executions and avoid executing Datchinamurthy Kataiah. The AGC refuted allegations and rumors related to Nagaenthran's case, denying any bias from Chief Justice Sundaresh Menon.

On the day of Nagaenthran's execution, the AGC released a statement addressing allegations and rumors related to the case, particularly those implying bias from Chief Justice Sundaresh Menon. The AGC noted that Nagaenthran's mother, who filed a lawsuit without her son's knowledge, was likely assisted by activists. The AGC emphasized that these allegations were baseless and constituted contempt of court. They also mentioned that Nagaenthran's counsel had been informed about Menon's appointment as Attorney General but made no objections. Following the execution, the AGC and Central Narcotics Bureau issued statements defending Singapore's decision amid international criticism.

After Nagaenthran's execution, the AGC reaffirmed that he received a fair trial and had utilized all available legal appeals over 11 years. The CNB emphasized that Nagaenthran's actions during the crime were deliberate and calculated, and he was aware of his actions at the time. They also addressed misinformation about his mental state. The Singaporean government, upheld by many, maintained that Nagaenthran underwent full due process. Following international criticism, particularly from the UN, Ambassador Umej Bhatia defended the government's decisions and the use of the death penalty, citing Singapore's reputation for a fair and impartial criminal justice system. Malaysia acknowledged the execution and reiterated respect for Singapore's sovereignty regarding its judicial system and laws.

In response to criticism, Ambassador Bhatia emphasized that criminal proceedings in Singapore are conducted fairly and without racial bias, with the death penalty being applied according to law. He also highlighted Singapore's long-standing reputation for a fair and impartial justice system and an independent judiciary. Minister Faishal Ibrahim stated that there would be consequences for abusing court processes, and he stressed the negative impact of drug abuse on individuals and society. The Singaporean government maintains its stance on its sovereign right to determine its criminal justice system and the continuation of its war on drugs.

During a BBC HARDtalk interview in June 2022, Shanmugam defended Singapore's continuation of the war on drugs and use of the death penalty as a means to protect citizens and maintain a safe society. He highlighted the decrease in drug-related arrests and cited a WHO report on drug-related deaths. Regarding the execution of Nagaenthran, Shanmugam stated that the courts found no evidence of intellectual disability and emphasized the severity of Southeast Asia's drug problem. The interview received support from many on social media. The Singaporean government remains firm in its stance on its sovereign right to determine its criminal justice system and drug policies.

In response to the BBC interview, opposition parties in Singapore, including Reform Party, People's Power Party, and Red Dot United, expressed concerns about lawyers being discouraged from representing drug traffickers on death row due to a perceived climate of fear. They wrote to Law Minister K Shanmugam, emphasizing the importance of legal representation under Singapore law and the potential damage to the country's reputation. This concern comes after Violet Netto, Nagaenthran's lawyer in his second-last appeal, was arrested for practicing without a valid certificate, which may further discourage lawyers from taking on such cases. Chief Justice Sundaresh Menon had previously addressed an increasing trend of baseless legal applications, especially in Nagaenthran's case, and urged lawyers not to abuse court processes.

Under Singaporean law, lawyers must have a valid practicing certificate for each practice year. However, Violet Netto, who represented Nagaenthran in his case, did not have a valid certificate and potentially faced penalties. Prior to this, M Ravi, another lawyer for Nagaenthran, faced multiple disciplinary inquiries, contempt proceedings, and police investigations, resulting in a travel ban. These incidents led to criticism from human rights groups and Malaysian lawyers, who accused Singapore of harassment and called for respect for the defendants' right to legal representation. Following this, the Court of Appeal ordered Ravi and Netto to pay over S$20,000 in costs to the Attorney-General's Chambers. Ravi, who also faced separate fines, remained defiant, stating he paid a heavy price for saving lives from capital punishment. Activists criticized Singapore for punishing the lawyers for fulfilling their duties.

After Nagaenthran's execution, Singapore passed a law imposing stricter regulations on post-appeal applications in capital cases. Now, only the Court of Appeal can grant a stay of execution and hear such applications. If a prisoner is found to have abused court processes, they will be barred from making further post-appeal applications unless new evidence emerges. Activists Kirsten Han and Rocky Howe were investigated for organizing assemblies against the death penalty without a permit. Ravi, another lawyer for Nagaenthran, faced penalties for not having a valid practicing certificate and was ordered to pay costs. He remained defiant, stating he paid a heavy price for saving lives from capital punishment. Critics argue that these actions from the Singaporean government are attempts to limit inmates' access to justice and suppress opposition.
